description: From Middle English ure, from Anglo-Norman *ure, Old French uevre (modern French œuvre), from Latin opera (“work, labor”). Doublet of oeuvre and opera.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, only in collocations in ure, out of ure) use, practise, exercise.
examples: But come, let vs be sure of this, to put the best in vre

verbs.description: ure (third-person singular simple present ures, present participle uring, simple past and past participle ured)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive, intransitive) To use; to exercise; to inure; to accustom by practice.
examples: […]  the French soldiers  […]  from their youth have been practised and ured in feats of arms  […]
